data.title: Frankly 20 — Revisiting Amy Winehouse’s Debut Two Decades Later
data.meta_description: “Our behavioural pa-erns that stick over the years,” Winehouse lilts to close the second verse of “What Is It About Men,” the gut-punching 9th track on her 2003 debut, Frank, released 20 years ago on…
data.text:
I vividly remember the moment I fell in love with Amy Winehouse.

My love blossomed in the space meant for two “t”s.

“Our behavioural pa-erns that stick over the years,” Winehouse lilts to close the second verse of “What Is It About Men,” the gut-punching 9th track on her 2003 debut, Frank, released 20 years ago on October 20th.

The open space disrupting the fluidity of the word “patterns” embodies the tao of Amy and all that made her so palpably beguiling. It’s raw. It’s vulnerable. It’s unexpectedly rhythmic where conventional wisdom dictates melody. It’s distinctly British, but not in the effete manner to which those of us west of the pond instinctively genuflect. It’s more Eliza Doolittle than Kate Middleton; the jagged edge signaling treacherous cracks in a sultry shell.

It didn’t take 9 tracks to cultivate my affection for Amy Winehouse. That solidified the moment the bassline dropped on “F**k Me Pumps.” I stumbled across Frank’s biting lead single on the internet through pure happenstance, as was prone to happen in the early days of the message board era.

Cosmetically, “F**k Me Pumps” fit comfortably enough into the neo-soul bin that, by…
